thread.title: Count Olaf is a devious delight in Netflix's A Series of Unfortunate Events trailer
thread.title_full: Count Olaf is a devious delight in Netflix's A Series of Unfortunate Events trailer

posts.author: Justin Harp
posts.title: Count Olaf is a devious delight in Netflix's A Series of Unfortunate Events trailer
posts.text: Netflix and Neil Patrick Harris's A Series of Unfortunate Events trailer is everything we'd hoped it'd be and more. Basically a cross between The Royal Tenenbaums and Edward Scissorhands, the delightfully grim adaptation of the Lemony Snicket book is bound to become your next Netflix obsession. Neil Patrick Harris wears many faces - all of them creepy as hell! - as Count Olaf, the schemer who's bent on stealing the orphaned Baudelaire children's fortune. Related: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events gets a Netflix launch date - AND a first-look teaser True Blood writer Mark Hudis's gorgeous adaptation of A Series of Unfortunate Events has a sensationally quirky cast - with Catherine O'Hara, Joan Cusack and Alfre Woodard all popping up in the teaser. Let's not forget Seinfeld and The Tick's Patrick Warburton as the series' way-too-aloof narrator Lemony Snicket, a pseudonym for the author Daniel Handler. Of course, Neil Patrick Harris steals the show as the devilish Count Olaf - a wealthy manipulator willing to say or do absolutely anything to achieve his greedy goals. Sound familiar? Harris has some big shoes to fill since Jim Carrey gloriously brought the evil Count Olaf to life in the original 2004 live-action movie Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events. The telly version of A Series of Unfortunate Events will finally arrive on Netflix on January 13, 2017. That's Friday the 13th - a very appropriate date if we do say so ourselves! Want up-to-the-minute entertainment and tech news? Just hit 'Like' on our Digital Spy Facebook page and 'Follow' on our @digitalspy Twitter account and you're all set.

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life': Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel bring 'more' to Netflix series
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life': Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel bring 'more' to Netflix series

posts.author: Canoe Inc.
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life': Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel bring 'more' to Netflix series
posts.text:
'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life': Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel bring 'more' to Netflix series Kelly Bishop, Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel in "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life." Latest News , Last Updated: 2:58 PM ET 
What does football have to do with the return of Gilmore Girls ? 
A number of years ago, a friend of mine was telling me that he was going to attend a U.S. college football game, taking place in one of those picturesque American college towns. And he was bringing his wife with him. 
I didn't know his wife was a football fan. He said she wasn't necessarily a football fan, but he explained the attraction. 
“She just loves that certain slice of Americana,” my friend explained. “You know, Gilmore Girls Americana.” 
Got it. Bingo. I knew exactly what he meant. 
I relayed that exact story to Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel, stars of the original series as well as the new four-part project Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life , which debuts Friday, Nov. 25, on Netflix. 
“Is that the small-town experience?” Bledel asked. 
Graham added, “Kind of simple and happy ... ” 
Yes, it's all that. The term Gilmore Girls Americana brings something specific to mind. And now we'll get to see how much of it still feels relevant in 2016, with the four new episodes of Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life encompassing specific seasons (Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall). 
“Oh boy, I don't know if it fits today, but I think people maybe appreciate that aspect of it,” Graham said. “I start to sound like Old Lady Jackson when I say, 'There's nothing on, there's nothing soothing to watch, I don't want to watch this violence and this meth lab and this, you know, whatever.' But I don't all the time. And I don't want reality TV to be our only option, as an actor. 
“So I think there are a number of reasons why the show has stuck around. But at the end of the day, there's something to be said for something you want to watch with a family member or friend, that isn't too stressful, but still is so intelligent and is really about something.” 
The original Gilmore Girls TV series aired for seven seasons, from 2000 to 2007. It focused on the lives and relationships of single-mom Lorelai Gilmore (Graham) and her then-teen daughter Rory (Bledel). Lorelai was only a teenager herself when she gave birth to Rory, so they were peers as much as they were mother-daughter, and usually Rory was the mature one. 
I guess Gilmore Girls always was a “dramedy,” even back before that term was so common. 
And it was a beloved “dramedy,” too. But it never got a proper ending. 
These days, to be honest, just about every long-running show that falls into the general category of “beloved” gets to have some sort of ending, if the creators want one. Fans demand such things. But a decade ago, that wasn't always the case. Beloved, long-running shows could be cancelled on short notice amid contract complications between networks, studios and actors, as was the case with Gilmore Girls. 
“The whole thing was unfinished,” Graham said. “We didn't know it was the end. Our director just mimicked a shot from the pilot, she was like, 'I gotta give people something, if it's going to be the end.' We were all up in the air. 
“So that, to some degree I think, is why we're sitting here (talking about Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life). It's not a grab for attention. It's just that, really, we didn't get to end the show. In Amy (Sherman-Palladino, series creator and executive producer) and Dan (Palladino, Amy's husband and also an executive producer), we have people who not only have more to say, they have 'more more' to say. She's like, 'I can't even put it all in these four episodes.' 
“It's like anyone who writes a successful character. It's why Batman is still around. Somebody's got something else to say about it. And it just happened that the world has evolved in such a way that a place to put it exists (Netflix).” 
Bledel said the cast and creators of Gilmore Girls had stayed in touch over the years, even as everyone was doing other things. 
Graham went on to star in Parenthood, which ran for six seasons on NBC. And Bledel did a number of self-described “strange” movie roles to test her boundaries. Her most memorable TV appearance was on Mad Men, where she played Beth Dawes, a disturbed young woman who had an affair with Pete Campbell (played by Vincent Kartheiser, who happens to be Bledel's real-life husband). 
Anyway, among the core group of Gilmore Girls alumni, the subject of revisiting this world obviously kept coming up. 
“Amy and I would talk sometimes, she'd check in with me and see what I was working on," Bledel said. "She expressed an interest in taking these characters further, and we talked about different possibilities from time to time. I knew she was interested in a more satisfying conclusion. But not even so much of a conclusion, it was that these characters still were very much alive for her. 
“So you can't ignore someone's creative impulses when it comes to something like that. We just kept talking about it.” 
And here we are, finally, back in the fictional town of Stars Hollow, Connecticut. 
The series is returning “in real time,” so to speak, so eight or nine years have passed since we last saw Lorelai and Rory. 
“I think it's more like nine years, I'm not sure why it's being written as eight everywhere,” Bledel said. “But nearly a decade is enough time for everybody to change quite a bit.” 
Not to the point of being unrecognizable, though. 
Lorelai still runs the Dragonfly Inn. And Rory, now in her 30s, has had some ups and downs in her journalism career. The last time we saw her, she had just graduated from Yale and was poised to cover Barack Obama’s presidential campaign. I don't think Rory could have predicted who's president now, huh? 
“(Rory) has been working hard, as she does,” Bledel said. “She started her work as a journalist at the same time as newspapers were going away. Her field changed dramatically as she was just kind of getting up and running. 
“So that's what we pick up with her. She has been living a bit of a vagabond lifestyle, kind of chasing each story that she becomes passionate about and wants to tell. So kind of crashing on couches and staying with friends, not necessarily planting roots anywhere.” 
We all know where Rory's roots are. Lorelai's, too. And in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, it doesn't take long for enduring, endearing, familial, familiar patterns to emerge. 
“The language, it has its own voice, you know?” Graham said. “And I learned this over the years, after I did the show, it was like, 'Now I have to find another part as good.' And then it was like, 'Wait a minute, that doesn't happen.' I found a world and a show (Parenthood) that was fantastic, but this particular kind of sense of humour, and mix of comedy and drama, it's Amy's thing. 
“So to have perspective on that, and then get to come back and feel a little more collaborative, we're all grown up now, we all can have a conversation about how great we want it to be. It just felt like we earned that over time. 
“This feels like the (original) show, but grown up. It was all nostalgia, and back to work, which was also nostalgia in its own way.” 
That's Gilmore Girls Americana for you. 
Kickoff is on Friday, Nov. 25. See you at the tailgate party. My friend and his wife will be there.

posts.author: Sean Keach
posts.title: Netflix wins Streaming Service of the Year at #TrustedReviewsAwards 2016
posts.text:
Home / News / Internet News / Netflix wins Streaming Service of the Year at #TrustedReviewsAwards 2016 Netflix wins Streaming Service of the Year at #TrustedReviewsAwards 2016 
by Sean Keach Read Comments 
Netflix has won Streaming Service of the Year at the TrustedReviews Awards 2016. 
The streaming giant, which began beaming television to us via the internet back in 2007, is hugely popular, boasting over 86 million paying subscribers worldwide. It’s available in 130 countries, and has been producing its own original movies and TV shows since 2013, back when House of Cards first arrived. 
Since then, Netflix has moved from strength to strength, and is now one of the most popular ways to consume media. With slick design, an incredible roster of content, and a unceasing willingness to innovate. It's little wonder then that it won this Readers' Choice category, 
Our Home Technology Editor and binge-watcher extraordinaire Ced Yuen had this to say: 
"From mailing out videos, to streaming third-party content, to creating its own TV shows and movies, Netflix has shown that it’s always keen to try new things. Netflix has had a lasting impact on the media industry as a whole, and there’s no denying its incredible success over the past two decades.” 
Better still, Netflix trumped some formidable rivals to take home the big prize, beating out Spotify, amazon Prime Video and Google Music for first place. 
Watch The Refresh: The best tech gossip and reviews every week 
Who do you think should have won this award? Let us know in the comments. 0 shares

posts.author: kluvrebekah
posts.title: Comedian Colin Quinn: The New York Subway Is Really The Best & Worst Of The World
posts.text:
Comedian Colin Quinn is headed back to Netflix with another standup special.
Directed by Jerry Seinfeld, Colin Quinn: The New York Story, hits the streaming service tomorrow, November 18th. It’s actually Quinn’s off-broadway show, which tackles the history of New York and the people who make the city great.

We had the chance to chat with Colin this morning about the special. If you love New York, you will love his show. He also added, if you hate New York, you will love this show. To say that Colin is excited about the show would be an understatement. He told us he just saw a poster for the show with his face on it…it was a small one on the subway, but he was excited nonetheless.
We also had to talk about SNL, since the shows have been so amazing during the election. We were just wondering if he missed being on the show. He doesn’t necessarily miss the show, but he would love to have been there after this epic election year.
We also brought up his friendship with Amy Schumer and he called her a brat! Ha!

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Cast Has a 'Brady Bunch' Moment for 'EW' Cover!
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' Cast Has a 'Brady Bunch' Moment for 'EW' Cover!

posts.author: Just Jared
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' Cast Has a 'Brady Bunch' Moment for 'EW' Cover!
posts.text:
There is just one more week to go until the new Gilmore Girls episodes debut on Netflix and this fun cover for Entertainment Weekly is getting us so excited!
The main cast members, including Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel , pose in Brady Bunch style photos and the result is too cute.
Also featured are Rory’s three guys – Jared Padalecki , Milo Ventimiglia , and Matt Czuchry – as well as Kelly Bishop , Scott Patterson , and Keiko Agena .
In the issue, Lauren talks about the change of pace in season seven when a new showrunner took over and Lorelai’s signature dialogue was different.
“I was in a scene in that seventh season and I thought, ‘Something feels so odd to me,’” she said. “And it was I was in a scene with two other people and I wasn’t talking. I thought, ‘I’ve never had this before.’”
For more from the issue, visit EW.com right now!

posts.title: It takes a while to spot what’s sci-fi about Black Mirror’s best episode
posts.text:
Netflix 
"Black Mirror" is known for dystopian visions of our tech-enhanced future. The episode everyone is talking about, though, is different.
"San Junipero" is the fourth episode of the Netflix-produced third season of the short film series.
Put it on and you may be struck, first, by the retro feel. Second, you may wonder what is sci-fi about it: the first act features no world-changing tech, only subtle hints in dialogue, music, and scenery that there's more than meets the eye. Finally, the ending is unlike any other in the series.
We've pulled highlights from the opening below. See if you can tell what's going on.
The episode opens in 1987, with a theater playing "The Lost Boys," a movie about two brothers who realize their California town is filled with vampires. Is that a clue? From "Black Mirror" San Junipero 

A car radio is playing the contemporary hit, "Heaven is a Place on Earth." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero 

Enter our protagonist, Yorkie, played by Mackenzie Davis from "Halt and Catch Fire." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero 

See the rest of the story at Business Insider

thread.title: It takes a while to spot what’s sci-fi about Black Mirror’s best episode
thread.title_full: It takes a while to spot what’s sci-fi about Black Mirror’s best episode

posts.author: Gus Lubin
posts.title: It takes a while to spot what’s sci-fi about Black Mirror’s best episode
posts.text:
print 
Netflix 
"Black Mirror" is known for dystopian visions of our tech-enhanced future. The episode everyone is talking about, though, is different. 
"San Junipero" is the fourth episode of the Netflix-produced third season of the short film series. 
Put it on and you may be struck, first, by the retro feel. Second, you may wonder what is sci-fi about it: the first act features no world-changing tech, only subtle hints in dialogue, music, and scenery that there's more than meets the eye. Finally, the ending is unlike any other in the series. 
We've pulled highlights from the opening below. See if you can tell what's going on. The episode opens in 1987, with a theater playing "The Lost Boys," a movie about two brothers who realize their California town is filled with vampires. Is that a clue? From "Black Mirror" San Junipero A car radio is playing the contemporary hit, "Heaven is a Place on Earth." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Enter our protagonist, Yorkie, played by Mackenzie Davis from "Halt and Catch Fire." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero "Am I dreaming?" asks a guy on a TV display. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero In walks the other lead, Kelly, played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw, with a guy hassling her. He says: "Could you please stop? We’ve only got a couple of hours so let’s use it." She replies: "I am using it." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Moments later in a club, Kelly sits down next to Yorkie to try to lose that guy. "Go along with whatever I say," Kelly says. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero "I need to talk with my friend here, ok?" Kelly says. "She’s sick. Like 'sick months to live' sick." Yorkie chimes in: "five, actually." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero The two women get a drink. Kelly says she likes Yorkie’s glasses: "People try so hard to look how they think they should look. They probably saw it in some movie. But I like these. They’re authentically you." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero "So you’re new here?" Kelly asks. "Wow, ok! Oh my God! We have to dance to this." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Yorkie lasts about 20 seconds on the dance floor before running outside. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Kelly joins her: "Sorry I pushed you into it," she says. "Saturday night’s once a week. It’s like no time. I get impatient." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Yorkie says everyone was looking at them—two girls dancing. Kelly tells her people are less uptight than they used to be. Yorkie confesses that she’s never been on a dance floor before, that she never does anything fun, and that she is engaged. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero But her fiancé isn’t here. "Wanna go to bed with me?" Kelly asks. "We could be back at mine in like [snap]." From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Yorkie, clearly torn, says she can’t. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero Yorkie walks alone in the rain. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero The camera pans down to a full moon in a puddle and cuts. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero The show jumps forward in time. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero 13 minutes have passed, and we still have almost no idea what’s going on. Yet there's an engaging story and something mysterious happening. As the show continues, we see how radically different this world is from ours—yet how realistic it might be. From "Black Mirror" San Junipero 
The other unusual thing about this episode? It's got an optimistic ending. 
"I really wanted to create something that felt different from what we’re used to at the moment, and I think that’s what’s really refreshing about it," director Owen Harris told The Hollywood Reporter . "It’s this world where you’re allowed to dance around to Belinda Carlisle, it’s a world of guilty pleasures but, because of the look and the feel of it, it’s larger than life, which makes everything a little bit more optimistic." 
Simply said, we wouldn't mind if someone really made San Junipero.

thread.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ Netflix revival will give fans a true ending
thread.title_full: ‘Gilmore Girls’ Netflix revival will give fans a true ending

posts.author: NICOLE BITETTE
posts.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ Netflix revival will give fans a true ending
posts.text:
‘Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life’ Netflix revival will hopefully give longtime fans the ending they deserve ‘Gilmore Girls’ Netflix revival will give fans a true ending   
“Gilmore Girls” is finally getting a true ending. 
The beloved series that followed quirky, fast-talking, coffee-loving mom-and-daughter pair Lorelai and Rory Gilmore ended its seven-season run in 2007 — but Netflix is bringing it back starting Nov. 25. 
The show's plot was left open-ended when it first went off the air, before creator Amy Sherman-Palladino could make the finale she envisioned. So fans are ecstatic. 
“It’s hard to not get your hopes up,” Kevin Porter, co-host of the “Gilmore Guys” podcast, tells the Daily News, adding that it’s not easy to recreate “lightning in a bottle.” 
Predictions for the ‘Gilmore Girls’ revival 
“There’s a reason for it to come back,” Porter continues. “(Sherman-Palladino) had a vision for a finale — there’s been dot, dot, dot at the end of this series forever. And we are finally going to get a period.” It’s just like old times! Rory and Lorelai enjoy takeout at the kitchen table in a scene from “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.” (Saeed Adyani/Netflix/Saeed Adyani/Netflix) 
Now, fans who once related to teenage Rory (Alexis Bledel) are approaching the age of her independent, single mother, played by Lauren Graham, who was in her early 30s show's outset. 
“I saw a little of myself in Rory,” die-hard fan Kate Goodin says of her earliest memories watching the gals. “Now that I’m older, I relate more to Lorelai. She’s my favorite character. She’s spunky, smart and totally true to herself.” 
Goodin, 30, who lives in Jersey City and is part of the community’s Gilmore Girls Appreciation Society — says it’s become even more interesting to follow Lorelai’s attempts at adult life, including how she navigated starting her own business and handled her dating life. 
“What would Lorelai do?,” Goodin said she always asked herself while dating. What will come of Lorelai and Luke in the revival? Fans are dying to know. (Saeed Adyani/Netflix) 
Porter believes everyone who watched the gals could relate with one of them in some way. 
“It reminds them of their own life, their relationship with their mothers or families ... or ‘I dated a Jess once,’ or ‘I dated a Logan,’” he says. 
Rory’s boyfriend choices were also a highly debated part of the series, leading fans to become so invested that they chose teams. See: Team Jess (Milo Ventimiglia), Team Logan (Matt Czuchry) and Team Dean (Jared Padalecki). The finale of what fans expected to be the last season ended with Rory turning down a proposal from her latest boyfriend, Logan.

thread.title: ‘Gilmore Girls': A Year in the Life Is Back On Netflix
thread.title_full: ‘Gilmore Girls': A Year in the Life Is Back On Netflix

posts.title: ‘Gilmore Girls': A Year in the Life Is Back On Netflix
posts.text:
‘Gilmore Girls': A Year in the Life Is Back On Netflix By Grace Jones   06:50 am Fresh from the Red Carpet the "Gilmore Girls": A Year in the Life stars look as if they have not aged after the original show stopped in 2007. (Photo : Kevin Winter/Getty Images) 
Netflix's "Gilmore Girls" revival stars walked the red carpet in L.A. for its official premiere. Four new episodes called 'A Year in the Life' returns after being gone a decade ago in 2007. What's amazing is, the personalities did not age at all. Advertisement 
Lauren Graham (Lorelai), Kelly Bishop (Emily), Alexis Bledel (Rory), Scott Patterson (Luke), Matt Czuchry (Logan), Liza Weil (Paris), David Sutcliffe (Christopher), Yanic Truesdale (Michel), Keiko Agena (Lane), are seen during the event who were also at Stars Hollow sets previously, as per TV Line. 
The early episodes of "Gilmore Girls" are trying to recreate the tiny Connecticut town of Stars Hollow in the original season. There's Luke (Scott Patterson) who gets impatient with freeloaders who request for his wifi password. Kirk (Sean Gunn) is fascinated with the money-making scheme. 
"Gilmore Girls" can depend on Lauren Graham for its success. She still attacks Amy Sherman-Palladino's brilliant dialogue perfectly for her character as Lorelai Gilmore. Two annoying women Lorelai, Rory (Alexis Bledel) and Emily (Kelly Bishop) get on the nerves of viewers for their selfishness. 
"A Year in the Life" foundation is somewhat thorny and painful. The Gilmore women mourn the demise of Emily's husband, Richard. He has a vital role in the clan and it is justifiable spending ample time to celebrate his life. It is indeed a good tribute also to actor Edward Herrmann, for the versatility of Richard all throughout those years. 
The heart of the episode revolves around Lorelai's feeling rejected by her own mother, Emily. She has never come to terms with her daughter's high spirit. She even condemned her when she got pregnant when she was still16 years old. Emily turns to Lorelai when she's afraid at the moment. They still argue just for the sake of wanting to control the family's story, according to Variety .   Related Articles

thread.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ revival review: Everything fans want
thread.title_full: ‘Gilmore Girls’ revival review: Everything fans want | GulfNews.com

posts.author: Saeed Adyani, Washington Post
posts.title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ revival review: Everything fans want
posts.text:
Let’s cut right to the chase, Gilmore Girls fans, and start with the good news: The Netflix revival of the beloved drama has everything you want. Lorelai and Rory return as the mother-daughter best-friend duo who live in the gloriously quirky town of Stars Hollow, Connecticut. The original creator and executive producers are in charge, ensuring the highly anticipated reboot is chock-full of callbacks, inside jokes and life updates on your favourite supporting characters. The bad news: It’s not perfect. It’s actually far from perfect. The revival has four 90-minute chapters, and it turns out that 42-minute episodes were the perfect amount of time before the famously sparkling dialogue and wacky plot lines start to drag — and characters’ flaws go from endearing to irritating.
The best news: Fans won’t care. Because Gilmore Girls is back.
Although television is cluttered with nostalgia projects, nothing quite strikes a chord like Gilmore Girls , which ran on the WB and the CW from 2000 to 2007. Executive producers Amy Sherman-Palladino and Dan Palladino couldn’t reach a financial deal with the studio and left before the seventh and final season, which was considered a huge disappointment, bogged down by nonsensical storylines. It all adds an extra layer of excitement to the revival, because viewers finally get to see the “real” ending.
As someone who has re-watched Gilmore Girls more times than I care to admit, hitting “play” on the first episode was nerve-racking. The magic of Gilmore Girls is buried deep in my psyche, as it is for many other fans, thanks to deeply relatable characters (Rory made it cool to be an introvert who loved to read!), sharp writing and the dream of living in a cosy town. Would the revival meet my sky-high expectations? Or would it confirm my fears that it could never live up to the actual series?
I’ll be honest — it was a little of both. Before viewing the episodes, Netflix required reporters to sign agreements in which we swore not to reveal any spoilers or surprises or specific plot points or twists or turns or ... any significant details whatsoever, especially about various romantic entanglements.
But here’s what I can tell you: The first episode is delightfully surreal. As in, is this really happening? Are Lorelai (Lauren Graham) and Rory (Alexis Bledel) bantering about coffee and trading pop culture references like no time has passed? The Stars Hollow Gazette gets a shout-out? Wait, town weirdo Kirk (Sean Gunn) has a pet pig? Actually, that seems about right.
Viewers get swept back into the all-consuming Gilmore world, starting in the wintertime. Each episode takes place in a different season over a year.
The theme of the revival is arriving at a crossroads (yes, Lorelai would make a Britney Spears joke here) and what to do when there are no easy answers. When we last saw Rory — the straight-A student with dreams of being a foreign correspondent — she had just graduated from Yale University with a job with a political website covering then-Sen. Barack Obama’s presidential campaign.
Although theoretically that would be quite the launch pad for a successful career, curiously, in the new series, it doesn’t come up at all. Now 32, Rory is struggling to find a permanent foothold in the fiercely competitive journalism world. On a trip home to Stars Hollow, she repeatedly assures her mother that she has a lot of irons in the fire (“I heard. You should become a blacksmith,” Lorelai deadpans), although she’s clearly terrified about her future.
Lorelai, meanwhile, is dealing with a midlife crisis of sorts, spending a fair amount of time in a (mostly bewildered) therapist’s office. She’s not just dealing with her complicated family issues: getting pregnant at 16 and running away from her wealthy, stifling parents. She’s also thinking about the future of the Dragonfly Inn, her dream business that she opened with her best friend, Sookie (Melissa McCarthy). Plus, she and grumpy diner owner Luke (Scott Patterson), the fan-favourite choice for her soulmate, aren’t all smooth sailing — even though the trailer features them sharing a kiss.
Threaded through the stories is the grief over the death of Edward Herrmann, who played Richard, Lorelai’s father; Herrmann died of cancer two years ago. In the revival, his widow, Emily (Kelly Bishop), grapples with life without her husband of 50 years.
She’s devastated, but still, she’s Emily Gilmore: Nothing can stop her from making a snarky comment to Lorelai, with whom she has a stormy relationship, or taking Luke down a peg. (Emily: “Luke.” Luke: “Yes?” Emily: “That was just my way of saying goodbye.”) And remember how she used to hire and fire maids every few days? Now, there’s a storyline with her non-English-speaking housekeeper, one that seems out of place for a TV show in 2016.
In the years since Gilmore Girls went off the air, some viewers have pointed out the show’s lack of diversity and its racial stereotypes, particularly Mrs. Kim (Emily Kuroda), the very strict Korean mother of Rory’s best friend Lane (Keiko Agena). Although Stars Hollow has evolved in many ways, much of the original tone remains the same — and there’s a hint at how the show feels about politically correct culture.
“Body shaming! Trigger warnings!” Lorelai sarcastically yells when Luke is upset that she’s eating tacos before a full dinner. “War on Christmas!”
One of the downsides of re-watching your favourite show is that the flaws become magnified. Many young women re-watch Gilmore Girls and realise they relate more to Lorelai than Rory, a scary reminder of the passage of time — and that Rory could be, well, kind of annoying.
All the characters have their negative traits, which are on display in the revival: Selfishness, the rash decisions that hurt others, the casual cruelty disguised as banter. Although it’s all part of making them well-rounded, binge-watching six hours of it in a row reinforces how your much-loved characters make poor choices.
This could be why Sherman-Palladino was upset when Netflix refused to release the episodes one week at a time, and instead will drop them all once, which is custom. Indeed, some advice: Ninety-minute Gilmore Girls episodes are not for binge-watching, at least not all in one sitting.
Not only do some of the characters become insufferable, but some expanded scenes are ones that don’t necessarily need expanding. For example, instead of a couple minutes of one of Stars Hollow’s typically terrible stage productions, there’s enough time to stretch it out for much longer.
Then again, maybe you love Stars Hollow musicals. Maybe you can’t get enough of Taylor Doose (Michael Winters) running the town meetings; or Paris Geller’s (Liza Weil) insults; or Lane’s band, Hep Alien; or references to Tori Spelling and Neil Patrick Harris.
That’s the one benefit of a Gilmore Girls mini-movie — with extended time and producers’ creative freedom, it’s a veritable buffet of every Gilmore experience imaginable. And for this show in particular, that’s all the fans really care about, anyway.
Don’t miss it
Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (four episodes) begins streaming on November 25 on Netflix.

thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' spoilers, news: Revival gets good reviews

posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life' spoilers, news: Revival gets good reviews
posts.text:
(Facebook/GilmoreGirls) "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" will premiere on Nov. 25 on Netflix. 
There are only a few days left before "Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" arrives on Netflix. And ahead of the momentous occasion, a second trailer has been released, a premiere party reunion was witnessed, and reviews have started pouring in. 
The cast recently reunited for a Netflix revival premiere party in Los Angeles. Almost everyone was there — from the titular Gilmore ladies, Lauren Graham, Alexis Bledel, and Kelly Bishop, to supporting cast members like Liza Weil, Scott Patterson, and Keiko Agena. 
"I'm just so thankful! I'm so thankful we made it," Graham told Entertainment Tonight . "And it's been such a big part of my life. I just got the feeling today, like, 'Oh, we can start to enjoy it now and share it with fans and not have to say no comment after we're asked any question.' So, it just feels really good." 
But that's not the only thing that's good. The reviews are in, and they have mostly been overwhelmingly positive. Fans of the original series will love the revival as it takes them back to a familiar place filled with the usual fast-paced dialogue and pop culture references. And while it can sometimes feel like too much, Maureen Ryan of Variety says that "it is television at its most warm and reassuring." Advertisement 
"Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" currently holds a 92 percent approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes . 
A second trailer was also released and it manages to strike nostalgia into fans while making them excited about what's to come. The mother-daughter dynamic is back and better than ever. But one thing that has caught the eyes of many is that only Jess (Milo Ventimiglia) gets a speaking line in the trailer out of the three main men in Rory's life. 
"I could have been a contender," Rory tells him. "You're still a contender," Jess replies. 
And while it may not seem like much, it was certainly enough for fans of the pairing to go wild with excitement that Jess and Rory may finally end up together. Furthermore, it was previously revealed that Rory and Dean (Jared Padalecki) only have one scene together. 
"Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life" will premiere on Nov. 25 on Netflix.

thread.title: The best foods to eat while you binge watch the Gilmore Girls revival
thread.title_full: The best foods to eat while you binge watch the Gilmore Girls revival

posts.author: alicejohnston2
posts.title: The best foods to eat while you binge watch the Gilmore Girls revival
posts.text:
I smell snow (Picture: Netflix) The Gilmore Girls revival is finally here.
Stay warm with this apple cider and honey hot toddy recipe For those who have been waiting for years, rewatching the inhabitants of Stars Hollow live their safely comforting, eccentric, happy lives, this week is going to be better than Christmas.
For those who have been living under a coffee cart or have been so incapacitated with excitement that you are no longer able to read, the four-part Gilmore Girls revival arrives this Friday on Netflix and will consist of four hour-long episodes, one for every season of the year.
‘Yes, Emily, you may go first’ *sobs* (Picture: Netflix) All our favourite characters are back and you will once again be able to stroll the Connecticut streets with them, clutching takeaway coffee cups and boxes of cornstarch.
Of course, a huge part of the show involves the food that Lorelei and Rory eat while they’re at town hall meetings, opening their own inns and working at The Franklin
(Picture: Netflix) While it may not be the healthiest food ever, the enjoyment that the Gilmore girls get from food and the bond that it creates between characters makes the show oh-so-cosy, comforting and fulfilling – much like a burger from Luke’s, in fact.
So, to feel as close to being a Stars Hollow citizen as is humanly possible (especially for us stuck in the UK who sadly can’t access any of the fabulous looking events being held by Netflix across the pond), here’s a list of foods to eat while you watch adoringly/sobbing/chuckling.
Pop Tarts (Picture: Giphy) A recurring theme, these delicious breakfast items are enjoyed by Rory and Lorelei on days when they don’t have time to get to Luke’s.
Pop tarts helped Lorelei to break away from her overbearing parents, signalling freedom and independence when she first tried them at a friend’s house.
MORE: Gilmore Girls’ Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel ‘shocked’ after discovering the show’s biggest secret 
Cheap and enjoyable, they’re a perfect entry level food to snack on while watching TV if you’re too anxious about whether Rory will choose Jess to eat a full meal (although frankly, I’m not sure you can call yourself a Gilmore Girls fan if you can’t put away a huge amount of junk food at a moment’s notice).
Pizza (Picture: Giphy) The classic, the unbeatable, the reliable, the saviour. Make like the Gilmore women and make pizza and TV your default fallback option.
Copy Lorelei helping Rory get over Dean the first time and get one with everything on it.
If that’s not your thing, go plain and simple like a snowed-in Emily and Richard with a frozen cheese and tomato offering.
But, whatever you choose, make sure to grate extra parmesan on top and don’t, for Gilmore’s sake, eat it with salad.
We’re not trying to emulate Dean here.
Dessert sushi Dreaming of some delicious candy sushi, Lorelei? (Picture: Netflix) Get to the next junk food level by creating your own sushi made of sweets.
Copyrighted by Lorelei, who made it to comfort Rory when she found out she wasn’t able to go to Asia with Logan because he had to go and work for his Dad, they are an inspired and vaguely disgusting concoction.
To make the sushi, acquire a pack of Fruit Winders (and flash back to junior school) and your desired candy-based filling.
More: Food Could you eat this 8,000 calorie sandwich stuffed with kebab meat? 
McDonald's has killed off its classic festive pie and Christmas is ruined 
This restaurant's response to a moaning customer is brilliant 
Lorelei favours a combo of red liquorice, chocolate chips, gummy sweets and mints but we feel sure that she would support any desires to cook up your own unique dessert sushi recipe.
Unroll the Winder and cut into appropriate size lengths for rolling, then apply some kind of sweet spread as glue – Marshmallow Fluff, Nutella or Biscoff spread would all be ideal – then pile on your sweets in a visually appealing pattern.
Roll up, Instagram and feel smug that you’ve made a nutritious and balanced dinner without even turning the oven on.
Blueberry pancakes (Picture: Giphy) Ideally, you’d want Luke to make these for you (and then conveniently forget to charge you for them as you rush out the diner on a whimsical errand), but if you have to be the Luke of your own life then just use any American pancake recipe.
After you’ve poured the batter into small pancake rounds in the pan, sprinkle blueberries on top before flipping them to cook through.
Serve with whipped cream, crispy bacon and maple syrup before dashing off to catch the bus to Chilton.
The devil’s starchy fingers (chips) (Picture: Giphy) A Mrs Kim special, Lane feeds Kyon, the Korean exchange student staying with her mother, a plate of fries to sustain her during Mrs Kim’s flaxseed muffin month.
Get them delivered, stick some frozen ones in the oven or go the whole potato and deep fry your own to enjoy a delicious plate of the devil’s starchy fingers on the comfort of your sofa.
Everything on the menu from your local Chinese (Picture: Giphy) Toast the return of your favourite show with the food held in your chopsticks!
Chinese takeout food appears again and again in this show as a weeknight staple, in a welcome-to-Yale buffet and as a way for Paris and Rory to get over their ex boyfriends.
For extra authenticity, order every chicken dish on the menu then serve it up cold the next day to the boy your daughter is pretending not to have a crush on while he’s taking a break from cleaning out your rain gutters.
Coffee, coffee, coffee with a shot of cynicism, served intravenously Don’t we all, Rory (Picture: Giphy) The only drink to wash down all the junk food with, except perhaps for an sensible single cup of Founder’s Day punch made by Miss Patty.
Whether you eat it, shoot it, drink it or snort it, ingest as many giant mugs of the Gilmore Girls chosen elixir as possible to keep you on the edge of your seat while you watch the reboot.
Copperboom, everyone! See you for Friday night dinner in Stars Hollow *sobs with anticipation*. MORE: When does Gilmore Girls start on Netflix? And everything else you need to know… 
MORE: Gilmore Girls cast refuse to call the Netflix revival ‘an ending’ sparking hope for fans

thread.title: 23 movies on Netflix that bookworms will love
thread.title_full: 23 movies on Netflix that bookworms will love

posts.title: 23 movies on Netflix that bookworms will love
posts.text:
Warner Bros. 

Whoopi Goldberg and Oprah Winfrey both made their film debuts in this adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. 2. The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo Columbia Pictures 
Before the American adaptation with Rooney Mara, there was this Swedish version with Noomi Rapace. 3. Forrest Gump Paramount Pictures 
The movie is so iconic that you might not have even known that it was based on a novel. 4. Into The Wild River Road Entertainment 
Emile Hirsch is absolutely captivating as Chris McCandless in this adaptation of Jon Krakauer's nonfiction book. 5. A Walk to Remember Warner Bros. 
Even if you're not normally a Nicholas Sparks fan, you know you cried when Mandy Moore sang "Only Hope" in this movie. 6. Silver Linings Playbook Weinstein Company 
The book was published just four years before Bradley Cooper and J.Law brought its protagonists to life on the big screen. 7. A Clockwork Orange "A Clockwork Orange"/Warner Bros./Columbia-Warner Distributors/Screenshot 
Anthony Burgess hated Stanley Kubrick's adaptation of his novel, but hey, you might like it. 8. The Shawshank Redemption 
One of the most highly-acclaimed films of the '90s was adapted from a Stephen King novella called Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption . 9. Anna Karenina Universal Pictures 
They somehow made an 864-page novel into a 129-minute movie, with Keira Knightley as the star. 10. The Kite Runner 
This moving film was based on the novel of the same name by Khaled Hosseini. 11. The Great Gastby Warner Bros. 
Fitzergald fans might find that this 1974 adaptation with Robert Redford feels a little more faithful to the famed novel than the 2012 remake does. 12. Full Metal Jacket 
Kubrick's famous war film was based on Gustav Hasford's semi-autobiographical novel The Short-Timers . 13. To Kill A Mockingbird Universal 
Gregory Peck gave an unforgettable performance as Atticus Finch in this 1962 film. 14. The English Patient 
This adaptation of Michael Ondaatje's novel won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1996. 15. The Boy In The Striped Pajamas Miramax 
I would only recommend watching this movie if you've already read the book and know exactly what to expect. 16. The Perfect Storm The Perfect Storm 
This movie was an adaptation of the nonfiction book of the same name by Sebastian Junger. 17. Philomena ABC 
You'll fall in love with Judi Dench as Philomena in this adaptation of The Lost Child of Philomena Lee. 18. What's Eating Gilbert Grape 
Leonardo DiCaprio received his first Academy Award nomination for his role in this movie. 19. Valley Of The Dolls Red Lion 
This cult film is almost as famous as the 1966 book upon which it was based. 20. Twelve Gaumont 
I'm still not totally sure why 50 Cent was in this adaptation of Nick McDonell's book. 21. Atonement Universal Pictures 
Saoirse Ronan was only 12 when she won the role of Briony in this dramatic film. 22. As I Lay Dying Picture Entertainment 
William Faulkner's famous 1930 novel was the basis for this film, which James Franco wrote, directed, and starred in. 23. Holes Walt Disney Pictures 
Shia LaBeouf starred in this beloved '00s adaptation of Louis Sachar's YA novel. 
You really can't go wrong with so many options for great movies that are based on books. Who said that the words "Netflix" and "literature" have to be mutually exclusive? Read the original article on Bustle . You can also check them out on Facebook and Pinterest . Copyright 2016. Follow Bustle on Twitter .

posts.title: Netflix to Release Three Dave Chappelle Specials
posts.text:
Dave Chappelle. Photo: Lester Cohen/WireImage 
Netflix is seriously beefing up its comedy lineup. After spending millions on two Chris Rock comedy specials in October, the site announced today that it will release three — count 'em, three — Dave Chappelle comedy specials. Netflix's order includes one all-new performance to be produced by the service, and two never-before-seen specials from Chappelle's "personal comedy vault" — though Chappelle has started to perform stand-up more often recently and even host SNL , Netflix's trio of shows will represent the comedian's first taped concert appearances in 12 years. The specials will all be released simultaneously in 2017, as the world moves from Peak TV to Peak Comedy.

posts.title: Netflix orders three Dave Chappelle stand-up specials - CNET
posts.text:
Up Next The biggest tech turkeys of 2016 
Comedian Dave Chappelle made a comeback on "Saturday Night Live" earlier this month and now the stand-up favorite has announced three new specials set to air simultaneously on Netflix next year. 
The projects help mark Chappelle's return to comedy. He walked out on the Comedy Central hit "Chappelle's Show" about a decade ago. 
"Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy -- searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential," said Lisa Nishimura, Netflix's VP of original documentary and comedy. "Dave's three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy." 
Stan Lathan is slated to direct the first stand-up show, along with two additional never-before-seen specials said to come from Chapelle's own personal comedy vault. 
A premiere date has not yet been announced. Share your voice

posts.title: Netflix And Dave Chappelle To Bring Three New Comedy Specials | Birth.Movies.Death.
posts.text:
Netflix And Dave Chappelle To Bring Three New Comedy Specials Chappelle’s coming back in a big way. By Evan Saathoff Nov. 21, 2016 
If anyone was wondering what Dave Chappelle would do next after his high-profile SNL hosting gig, here’s your answer. The guy’s about to come out with three new standup specials, all of them for Netflix, the official place where dreams come true. 
One of these specials will be brand new. The other two will be older performances, one from Austin City Limits, the other from The Hollywood Palladium. Those latter two will come out at the same time next year. We don’t yet know when the brand new special will arrive. 
As his SNL proved, Chappelle’s still hilarious but doesn’t hold back from speaking his mind, even at the risk of saying something unpopular. It’ll be interesting to see how much of either hallmark these three specials have to offer. I certainly can’t wait to find out. Related Product: Dave Chappelle: Killin' Them Softly DVD | Urban Works

thread.title: Movies on Netflix that bookworms will love
thread.title_full: Movies on Netflix that bookworms will love - Business Insider

posts.author: Allie Funk, Bustle
posts.title: Movies on Netflix that bookworms will love
posts.text:
Tom Hanks in "Forrest Gump," now available on Netflix. YouTube
The INSIDER Summary:
• Movie adaptations of books can bring them to life or ruin them.
• Here are some of the best book-to-movie adaptations on Netflix right now.
• Highlights include classics like Forrest Gump and tearjerkers like A Walk To Remember.
There are a wide variety of movies based on books on Netflix , so that means there are plenty of chances to either love or detest seeing your favorite literary works in cinematic form. After all, bookworms often have a love-hate relationship with movie adaptations of books. On the one hand, there's the excitement of seeing your favorite authors' work get recognized in such a big way, and watching their stories and characters come to life on the big screen. On the other hand, there's an uncomfortable conflict if the portrayals onscreen don't match the story you pictured in your head, particularly if it's a book that you've read many times (and therefore probably have some very set feelings about).
Additionally, sometimes a movie is already "ruined" for you if you've read the book and therefore know how the story ends. For example, the movie Fight Club would have a very different impact on someone who had already read the book than it would on someone who was going in fresh. It's also worth nothing that not all book-to-movie adaptations are created equal, and sometimes the screen version of a certain novel is just bad. It's disappointing when that does happen, but the good news is that there are plenty of other adaptations that are worth watching. Here are some movies available to stream on Netflix that any bookworm will enjoy.
 1. The Color Purple Warner Bros.
Whoopi Goldberg and Oprah Winfrey both made their film debuts in this adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel.
2. The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo Columbia Pictures Before the American adaptation with Rooney Mara, there was this Swedish version with Noomi Rapace.
3. Forrest Gump Paramount Pictures The movie is so iconic that you might not have even known that it was based on a novel.
4. Into The Wild River Road Entertainment Emile Hirsch is absolutely captivating as Chris McCandless in this adaptation of Jon Krakauer's nonfiction book.
5. A Walk to Remember Warner Bros. Even if you're not normally a Nicholas Sparks fan, you know you cried when Mandy Moore sang "Only Hope" in this movie.
6. Silver Linings Playbook Weinstein Company The book was published just four years before Bradley Cooper and J.Law brought its protagonists to life on the big screen.
7. A Clockwork Orange "A Clockwork Orange"/Warner Bros./Columbia-Warner Distributors/Screenshot Anthony Burgess hated Stanley Kubrick's adaptation of his novel, but hey, you might like it.
8. The Shawshank Redemption Columbia Pictures via YouTube One of the most highly-acclaimed films of the '90s was adapted from a Stephen King novella called Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption .
9. Anna Karenina Universal Pictures They somehow made an 864-page novel into a 129-minute movie, with Keira Knightley as the star.
10. The Kite Runner Dreamworks SKG This moving film was based on the novel of the same name by Khaled Hosseini.
11. The Great Gastby Warner Bros. Fitzergald fans might find that this 1974 adaptation with Robert Redford feels a little more faithful to the famed novel than the 2012 remake does.
12. Full Metal Jacket YouTube/Jimmy Jammz Kubrick's famous war film was based on Gustav Hasford's semi-autobiographical novel The Short-Timers .
13. To Kill A Mockingbird Universal Gregory Peck gave an unforgettable performance as Atticus Finch in this 1962 film.
14. The English Patient Miramax This adaptation of Michael Ondaatje's novel won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1996.
15. The Boy In The Striped Pajamas Miramax I would only recommend watching this movie if you've already read the book and know exactly what to expect.
16. The Perfect Storm The Perfect Storm This movie was an adaptation of the nonfiction book of the same name by Sebastian Junger.
17. Philomena ABC You'll fall in love with Judi Dench as Philomena in this adaptation of The Lost Child of Philomena Lee.
18. What's Eating Gilbert Grape Paramount via YouTube Leonardo DiCaprio received his first Academy Award nomination for his role in this movie.
19. Valley Of The Dolls Red Lion This cult film is almost as famous as the 1966 book upon which it was based.
20. Twelve Gaumont I'm still not totally sure why 50 Cent was in this adaptation of Nick McDonell's book.
21. Atonement Universal Pictures Saoirse Ronan was only 12 when she won the role of Briony in this dramatic film.
22. As I Lay Dying Picture Entertainment William Faulkner's famous 1930 novel was the basis for this film, which James Franco wrote, directed, and starred in.
23. Holes Walt Disney Pictures Shia LaBeouf starred in this beloved '00s adaptation of Louis Sachar's YA novel.
You really can't go wrong with so many options for great movies that are based on books. Who said that the words "Netflix" and "literature" have to be mutually exclusive?
Read the original article on Bustle . You can also check them out on Facebook and Pinterest . Copyright 2016. Follow Bustle on Twitter .

posts.title: Dave Chappelle Brings Three New Stand-Up Specials to Netflix
posts.text:
All Stories 
After Dave Chappelle 's long-anticipated return to television hosting Saturday Night Live , the comedian announced he will air three new stand-up specials on Netflix in 2017. The trio includes one original new set and two never-aired live performances from Austin City Limits and the Hollywood Palladium, respectively. Related Dave Chappelle on 'SNL': 3 Sketches You Have to See "Hillary Clinton" singing Leonard Cohen's "Hallelujah," host's powerful monologue and Chris Rock cameo in Election Day sketch highlight episode 
The new special marks Chappelle's first in 12 years since Dave Chappelle's Block Party came out in 2005. The specials will appear on the streaming service simultaneously. No airdate has been announced. 
"Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy – searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential,” said Netflix executive Lisa Nishimura in a statement. “Dave’s three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy, and we are honored he will mark his global return on Netflix. 
Netflix previously reached a two-comedy specials deal with Chris Rock in October, Variety reported . More News

posts.text:
Dave Chappelle is coming to Netflix .
The stand-up comedian has cut a deal with the streaming service for three new comedy specials starting in 2017, according to Netflix. As of now, the premiere date has not been set.
News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 
— Netflix US (@netflix) November 21, 2016 

"Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy--searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential," Lisa Nishimura, Netflix's VP of original documentary and comedy, said in a press release emailed to Fortune . "Dave's three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy.”
 
Chappelle is slated to work with director Stan Lathan to produce an original special for Netflix nflx . The other two projects will come from Chappelle's personal comedy vault: The first was produced at the Austin City Limits venue and the second at the Hollywood Palladium in 2015 and 2016, respectively.
The projects are Chappelle’s first stand-up TV specials in 12 years, according to Netflix, and are on the heels of his first hosting gig at Saturday Night Live earlier this month. His performance generated the show's highest ratings in three years.

posts.text:
Dave Chappelle releases 3 Netflix specials Associated Press 10:46 AM, Nov 21, 2016 Share Article Comedian Dave Chappelle speaks on stage at the RUSH Philanthropic Arts Foundation’s Art for Life Benefit at Fairview Farms in Water Mill on Saturday, July 18, 2015, in New York. (Photo by Scott Roth/Invision/AP) Scott Roth Previous Next 
NEW YORK (AP) — Comedian Dave Chappelle is headed back to TV with his first concert specials in a dozen years — a trio of specials to be released on Netflix simultaneously in 2017. 
No exact date was given by Netflix, which said one of the specials is being produced exclusively for the network. Two additional never-before-seen specials "come directly from Chappelle's personal comedy vault," Netflix said. 
Chappelle's comedy career includes movie roles in "The Nutty Professor,"''Con Air" and "Blue Streak." In 2003, he achieved heightened fame and critical acclaim as mastermind of his Comedy Central sketch series, "Chappelle's Show," until his abrupt exit in its third season. 
Earlier this month, he made his hosting debut on NBC's "Saturday Night Live," mixing one-liners with serious jabs at race relations and politics. Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

posts.author: The Master Chief
posts.title: Dave Chappelle Teams Up With Netflix for THREE New Comedy Specials
posts.text:
Netflix announced today that they have teamed up with legendary funnyman Dave Chappelle for not just one, not two, but THREE brand new comedy specials.
The big announcement comes just one week after Chappelle’s SNL appearance in which he showed the world that he’s ‘still got it’ after all these years.
News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 
— Netflix US (@netflix) November 21, 2016 

“Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy — searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential,” Netflix’s vice president of original documentary and comedy Lisa Nishimura said in a statement Monday (Nov. 21). “Dave’s three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy.”
One of the specials will be an original set that was filmed exclusively for Netflix, and the other two will come from previously unreleased comedy sets that were recorded at Austin City Limits Live and the Hollywood Palladium.
Chappelle’s Netflix comedy specials will be his first TV specials in 12 years. Though no dates have officially been announced, the two already-recorded specials will be released simultaneously in 2017.
Netflix is showing that they are interested in taking over stand-up comedy as the news of Dave Chappelle’s deal comes just over a month after the company responsible for the slow death of cable TV as we know it announced that it had ordered two specials from Chris Rock in a $40 million deal.
Netflix has also released comedy specials featuring Aziz Ansari, David Cross and Patton Oswalt.

posts.author: Hilton Hater
posts.title: Dave Chappelle Comedy Specials: Headed to Netflix!
posts.text:
Dave Chappelle is officially, 100%, totally and completely back.
The comedian, who received rave reviews for his Saturday Night Live hosting stint on November 12, has signed a pretty major deal with Netflix.
Scroll down for details...
The streaming company has announced on Twitter that it will release a trio of new comedy specials from Chappelle at various points in the near future.
No release dates have been revealed as of this writing.
However, we can confirm that one of the specials will be an original set filmed exclusively for Netflix, while the remaining two wil be from “Chappelle’s personal comedy vault” and were filmed at Austin City Limits Live and the Hollywood Paladium.
The following Tweet is the extent of the information Netflix has provided us with:
“Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy - searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential,” said Lisa Nishimura, VP of Original Documentary and Comedy said via statement, adding:
“Dave’s three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy, and we are honored he will mark his global return on Netflix.”
Always a beloved and respected comedian, Chappelle struck it huge in 2003 with his Comedy Central sketch program, Chappelle's Show
It was a critical and ratings hit and the network at the time offered him $50 million to film three more years of the series.
After initially agreeing to this deal and setting May 31, 2005 premiere date for Season 3, Chappelle stunned fans and the entertainment industry when he abruptly left during production and took a trip to South Africa.
It was reported by some at the time that he suffered some kind of nervous breakdown.
"Coming here, I don't have the distractions of fame. It quiets the ego down," he said at one point during his international sabbatical.
"I'm interested in the kind of person I've got to become. I want to be well-rounded and the industry is a place of extremes. I want to be well-balanced. I've got to check my intentions, man."
Chappelle remained mostly out of the spotlight ever since taking this hiatus.
But he hosted SNL for its first show after Donald Trump was elected President, striking the perfect balance of seriousness, comedy and insight and pretty much announcing his comeback in the process.
Now, thanks to his deal with Netflix, he's likely on his way back to making up for a lot of the $50 million he left on the table over a decade ago.

posts.title: Dave Chappelle will grace the small screen again on 3 new Netflix specials
posts.text:
Dave Chappelle will grace the small screen again on 3 new Netflix specials By: Nicole Cormier Nov 21, 2016 3 hours ago 17 6 y2016m11d21 110373 Netflix 
Netflix has been capitalizing where other providers have been falling short, as marked by their successful original programming that both pushes the envelope and caters to nostalgia. Their latest announcement fits into both categories. The streaming provider took to Twitter to announce three new Dave Chappelle comedy specials will be coming soon. 
The last special the comedian was involved in outside of the wildly beloved "Chappelle’s Show," came in 2004, and soon after he discontinued his work on the sketch comedy show that shared his name, to much media speculation. Since then, Chappelle has continued to perform stand-up, which is his first love, playing surprise dates all over the country. Most recently, the comedian revived his sketch comedy genius on Saturday Night Live , delivering scathing political commentary, when the country needed it most. 
Although Netflix hasn’t given any details about the timing or theme of the new specials, but at this point, his fans will just be happy to see him on their TVs again. News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 — Netflix US (@netflix) November 21, 2016 By: Nicole Cormier Nov 21, 2016 Added 3 hours ago Sponsor

thread.title_full: Dave Chappelle sets three Netflix comedy specials - Chicago Tribune

posts.author: Tribune news services
posts.title: Dave Chappelle sets three Netflix comedy specials
posts.text:
Dave Chappelle has cut a deal with Netflix for three new comedy specials.
The projects will mark Chappelle's first standup TV specials in 12 years, and it marks another aggressive push by Netflix in the standup comedy arena.
"Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy -- searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential," said Lisa Nishimura, Netflix's VP of original documentary and comedy. "Dave's three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy."
The deal calls for Chappelle and director Stan Lathan to produce an original special for Netflix. Two other unreleased projects will come from Chappelle's vault -- one produced out of the Austin City Limits venue, the other from a performance at the Hollywood Palladium.
MOST READ ENTERTAINMENT NEWS THIS HOUR
The projects from the vault are set for release simultaneously next year. There's no premiere date yet for the new special.
Chappelle is coming off a strong performance earlier this month as host of "Saturday Night Live," which generated the show's highest ratings in three years. He is among the most prolific and successful touring comics in country, staging some 500 shows during the past three years.
Netflix made headlines last month by setting a $40 million deal with Chris Rock for two new comedy specials.

Dave Chappelle is the perfect host for the first 'Saturday Night Live' in Trump's America
Fake Donald Trump returns to 'SNL,' and the real one is not happy

posts.title: Netflix is bringing three new Dave Chappelle comedy specials to you
posts.text:
Netflix is bringing three new Dave Chappelle comedy specials to you Posted by Kevin McGuire on Nov 21, 2016 13:40 Not long after Dave Chappelle served as host of Saturday Night Live comes word Chappelle is set to have three brand new comedy specials airing exclusively on Netflix. News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 
It’s been a long time coming for Chappelle fans. 
“Dave Chappelle is a legendary voice in comedy — searing, vital, and now more than ever, essential,” said Netflix Vice President of Original Documentary and Comedy (that is quite a title) Lisa Nishimura. “Dave’s three new specials promise to be some of the most anticipated events in comedy.” 
They will absolutely be anticipated. The last time Chappelle had a comedy special on TV was 12 years ago. It should be expected he will have plenty of material to use since his last special. Stan Latham will be the producer and will co-direct with Chappelle for a brand new, original comedy special. 
Two others will actually be pulled from archives to show off performances from Austin City Limits and the Hollywood Palladium. Those two specials from the vault are due out in the next year, but a date for the original special has not been announced at this time. 
This country is going to need some laughter in 2017 and beyond, and Chappelle will be there to help provide it. 
[ Variety ] About Kevin McGuire Contributor to NBCSports.com's College Football Talk, Athlon Sports and The Comeback. Host of the No 2-Minute Warning Podcast on iTunes, Stitcher Radio and iHeart Radio. FWAA member and Philadelphia-area resident.

thread.title: 'Gilmore Girls' makes triumphant return to Netflix
thread.title_full: 'Gilmore Girls' makes triumphant return to Netflix

posts.author: LUAINE LEE Tribune News Service
posts.title: 'Gilmore Girls' makes triumphant return to Netflix
posts.text:
November 21, 2016 3:00 AM 'Gilmore Girls' makes triumphant return to Netflix By LUAINE LEE Tribune News Service Order Reprint of this Story BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. 
Just when we thought the Gilmore Girls had shuffled off to the TV bone yard, they are back, chatting like rappers on speed and proving you can go home again. 
Creator-writer, Amy Sherman-Palladino, has assembled most of the original cast of the long-running "Gilmore Girls" series for four new 90-minute episodes. They transport the audience over the course of a year in "Gilmore Girls: a Year in the Life." The series begins streaming Friday on Netflix. 
It's been 10 1/2 years since the young single mom (Lauren Graham) and her precocious daughter (Alexis Bledel) bonded their way into adulthood, while on-again-off-again boyfriend (Scott Patterson) bided his time. 
"It's not a story about a little girl anymore, who's in high school," says Graham, 49, who has since costarred in "Parenthood,""Web Therapy,""The Odd Couple." 
"It's a story about a young woman and kind of the struggles she faces. Yet the dynamics ... between these two characters, they've grown up, but they're the same. And that kind of foundation of 'Here are the people you have to rely on' can take you through any age. I think that's what this show continues to tell us about family anyway," she says. 
Sherman-Palladino didn't harbor much hope that her girls would ever see the quaint town of Stars Hollow again. "When Netflix popped up and decided to storm the world and just take over overnight, we thought, 'Well, what a great opportunity to delve into a different form, to tell stories in a different way using beloved characters that we loved'" she says. 
"And we get back in a room with these three actors and to be able to go at it again, but in a completely different way ... There was no grand Master Plan. It was just, 'Hey, there's a Netflix now, which means we could do a billion minutes because we have a lot of words, and ... it was a different form. 
"You're writing not to commercials or to sell soap or tampons. Nobody gives a s_. It's really just there to tell stories. And it was just such an exciting challenge, and form, and a way to get us all back together again and put on a show." 
Bledel, who's 25 and has since costarred in "Mad Men,""Us & Them,""Jenny's Wedding," says falling back into the role was like riding a bike. "It really was as if no time had passed," she says. 
"It's all on the page. Amy's writing just informs you right away. You know how it's supposed to be said, and it's all there for you ... It's amazing to know that people are eagerly awaiting the release of these episodes, and that they have loved the show all these years ... It's why we do this, to be able to communicate something that people are going to love and talk about and enjoy it together." 
It's more than just enjoyment, says Patterson, 58, who has costarred in "Aliens in America,""Meth Head,""The Event." He says the original show has left its indelible mark on those we least expect. 
"I was walking through the Austin airport, and a fellow walked up to me and just started crying, and he said he was in a sniper battalion in Iraq, in Fallujah, and he had done four tours. And they watched 'Gilmore Girls' obsessively. It's a safe place for them. It's like nothing bad can happen while they're watching that show. He even got his commanding officer on the cell phone, who was in Fort Bragg and about to be shipped back over. And he said, 'I'm standing here with Luke.' And he goes, 'F_ no!' I mean, it was just this huge reaction. It was kind of amazing." 
"I do want to say what was so great about this (project) is I really feel like we got to do it together," says Sherman-Palladino. 
"The first show was, like: You cast. You get on a plane. You don't know anyone. You're in Canada. It's cold. You're wandering around. It's like you're exhausted. There's elevensies. I don't know what it is, it's like 'Lord of the Rings.' And then you're in this whirlwind of production, and you're tired, and you're sick, and you don't feel well, and you're throwing up, and you don't remember when you got your hair done last, and then it's over. 
"And this time I felt like, because we would talk, and we were all in contact, and it felt like we got to sit and say, 'Do we want to go on this journey together? Do we want to band together and like - Mickey Rooney-Judy Garland, this s _?' And for me ... there will be nothing else in my career like what we got to do." 
HOLIDAY SPECIALS FOR THANKSGIVING WEEKEND 
There will be plenty of holiday specials to watch Thanksgiving weekend once that turkey has nestled in your stomach and you have begun to ease on down to the couch. ABC will feature "The Wonderful World of Disney: the Magical Holiday Celebration" at 8 p.m. 
You can march to a different drummer with the "Thanksgiving Day Parade" on CBS or NBC in the morning. How about joining "The Simpsons" for their 24-hour marathon on FXX or recite along with the cast of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show" on IFC? 
Friday CBS will dish out two 30-minute "Frosty the Snowman" shows, CW will describe how "Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer.""Terrific Trucks Save Christmas' will skid over to Sprout and ï¿½ in case you don't remember that far back - "The '90s: the Last Great Decade" will air its marathon all day on NatGeo Channel. And don't forget that PBS sports a brand new version of "Anne of Green Gables" airing Thursday. (Check local listings). 
ALAN THICKE TO HOST NEW SHOW 
Alan Thicke will be back in the thick of things when he hosts "Entertainment Weekly Presents: '80s Stars - Where are They Now?" (long enough title?) on REELZ starting Nov. 30. 
Thicke, who starred in "Growing Pains" and hosted his own talk show, tells me he's done standup comedy too. "But that's really not my background. It's one thing to be witty or clever or fast. It's another thing to have the rhythm that's involved in the art - and I do consider it an art - of standup comedy. Those guys succeed where the rest of us fail. I was very successful in daytime in Canada with a (talk) type show because of the ability to react, be light on my feet and have a quip and whatnot - but not to have to score all the time yourself - being able to share spotlight with your guests." 
DAMON WAYANS STARTED OUT ON THE WRONG FOOT 
Damon Wayans and his partner Clayne Crawford are two of the most popular guys on TV with their new fall show on Fox, "Lethal Weapon." Wayans, who's known for his comedy timing and creativity from "In Living Color," says it all started out wrong for him. 
"I got thrown out of three different high schools. 'Yea! I'm pretty funny.' I was the class clown and had a running commentary on everything, whatever anyone threw out I had a response. That came from insecurity. When I first started out in comedy you tend to do that, you want to prove your wit, everything someone says, you try to find comedy in it." 
(Luaine Lee is a California-based correspondent who covers entertainment for Tribune News Service.) Related content

posts.title: Dave Chappelle will grace the small screen again on 3 new Netflix specials
posts.text:
Dave Chappelle will grace the small screen again on 3 new Netflix specials By: Nicole Cormier Nov 21, 2016 5 hours ago 17 6 y2016m11d21 110373 Netflix 
Netflix has been capitalizing where other providers have been falling short, as marked by their successful original programming that both pushes the envelope and caters to nostalgia. Their latest announcement fits into both categories. The streaming provider took to Twitter to announce three new Dave Chappelle comedy specials will be coming soon. 
The last special the comedian was involved in outside of the wildly beloved "Chappelle’s Show," came in 2004, and soon after he discontinued his work on the sketch comedy show that shared his name, to much media speculation. Since then, Chappelle has continued to perform stand-up, which is his first love, playing surprise dates all over the country. Most recently, the comedian revived his sketch comedy genius on Saturday Night Live , delivering scathing political commentary, when the country needed it most. 
Although Netflix hasn’t given any details about the timing or theme of the new specials, but at this point, his fans will just be happy to see him on their TVs again. News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 — Netflix US (@netflix) November 21, 2016 By: Nicole Cormier Nov 21, 2016 Added 5 hours ago Sponsor

posts.title: Netflix announces Dave Chappelle comedy special
posts.text:
November 21, 2016 Robert Galvan Netflix announces Dave Chappelle comedy special 
Netflix quietly announced that it will be producing a Dave Chappelle comedy special on its twitter today. Unless you have lived under a rock for the past 20 years, you probably recognize Dave Chappelle as one of the funniest and most original comedians of all time. His short-lived skit comedy show was only around for 3 seasons but is still recognized today. Recently, Saturday Night Live had Chappelle host for the first time in history which reintroduced characters from his show that ended 10 years ago. 
We will let you know when more information is given, but for now, celebrate in anticipation for what will sure to be a memorable comedy special. News: 3 new Dave Chappelle comedy specials, coming soon. pic.twitter.com/OzrDukBPk6 
— Netflix US (@netflix) November 21, 2016 
And here is the SNL monologue video.

posts.text: 57PM NEW YORK -- Comedian Dave Chappelle is headed back to TV with his first concert specials in a dozen years - a trio of specials to be released on Netflix simultaneously in 2017.No exact date was given by Netflix, which said one of the specials is being produced exclusively for the network. Two additional never-before-seen specials "come directly from Chappelle's personal comedy vault," Netflix said.Chappelle's comedy career includes movie roles in "The Nutty Professor," "Con Air" and "Blue Streak." In 2003, he achieved heightened fame and critical acclaim as mastermind of his Comedy Central sketch series, "Chappelle's Show," until his abrupt exit in its third season.Earlier this month, he made his hosting debut on NBC's "Saturday Night Live," mixing one-liners with serious jabs at race relations and politics. thread.title: Netflix announces major deal with comedian Dave Chappelle
thread.title_full: Netflix announces major deal with comedian Dave Chappelle

posts.author: Sara Gonzales
posts.title: Netflix announces major deal with comedian Dave Chappelle
posts.text:
Tweet 
Internet streaming service Netflix has announced a major deal with Dave Chappelle , who is widely regarded as one of the most successful comedians of the last quarter-century. According to the terms of the deal, Chappelle is set to release three new full-length comedy specials exclusive to the Netflix service. 
Chappelle’s career includes a number of major film appearances, including the starring role in the cult comedy “Half Baked.” Chappelle’s eponymous Comedy Central show was one of the cable network’s most highly-rated and culturally enduring shows. 
Creative conflicts with Comedy Central led to Chappelle’s decision to walk off of production from the show during its third season, spurning a rumored contract offer of $55 million and stunning fans and television executives alike. Chappelle stuck mostly to live stand-up for years, but he made a major splash by hosting the first “Saturday Night Live” after President-elect Donald Trump’s victory: the episode garnered the highest ratings for the show since Jimmy Fallon hosted in 2013. 
Netflix’s deal with Chappelle represents the latest attempt by Netflix to aggressively compete with cable networks in original content, particularly in the realm of televised stand-up comedy. Netflix also recently announced that they had inked comedian Chris Rock — who joined Chappelle for a widely-circulated skit on this week’s “Saturday Night Live” — to a lucrative two-special deal. The financial terms of the deal with Chappelle have not yet been disclosed. Rate this story

Netflix’s deal with Chappelle represents the latest attempt by Netflix to aggressively compete with cable networks in original content, particularly in the realm of televised stand-up comedy. Netflix also recently announced that they had inked comedian Chris Rock — who joined Chappelle for a widely-circulated skit on this week’s “Saturday Night Live” — to a lucrative two-special deal. The financial terms of the deal with Chappelle have not yet been disclosed. Rate this story

HIGHLIGHTS A new special and 2 never-seen performances, coming in 2017 Comic recently appeared on ‘Saturday Night Live’ Acclaimed standup comedian Dave Chappelle, who has kept his career low-key since ending his Emmy-nominated Comedy Central sketch series “Chappelle’s Show” in 2006, will debut three Netflix specials next year. 
The streaming-video service said Monday that Chappelle, 43, and director Stan Lathan (Chappelle’s 2005 Emmy-nominated special “For What It’s Worth”) will produce a new special and also release “two additional never-before-seen specials . . . directly from Chappelle’s personal comedy vault.”
